Ester hydrogenolysis is industrially performed over Adkins catalysts. Their use is being restricted as they contain environmentally unfriendly Cr2O3. As a potential replacement, five co-precipitated CuZnAl catalysts with various Cu/Zn and Al/(Cu+Zn) atomic ratios were studied. The structure transformation during the whole catalyst lifecycle was determined. The catalyst precursors consisted of CuZnAl-hydrotalcite (HTC). Although the Cu/Zn ratio did not affect the HTC structure, an increase in Al content resulted in smaller Cu nanoparticles with a larger surface area. In the reduced catalysts, both Cu+ and Cu0 species were identified using FTIR-CO. XPS revealed catalyst surface reconstruction after catalyst reduction and catalytic reaction. The evaluation of the catalysts in dimethyl adipate hydrogenolysis indicated that the catalyst having the lowest Cu loading possessed the highest activity, due to its high SCu and Cu/Zn = 1. Generally, higher activity was achieved by reducing the Cu/Zn and increasing the Al/(Cu+Zn) ratios. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Copper Zinc Hydrotalcite Ester hydrogenolysis Dimethyl adipate Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent years, interest in the application of green chemistry principles to catalytic processes has increased significantly [1]. Accordingly, the process of alcohol production by ester hydrogenolysis is a prime candidate for substantial refinement. In particular, dimethyl adipate (DMA) to hexane-1,6-diol (HDOL) hydrogenolysis requires improvement in two key areas: feedstock sustainability and catalyst toxicity. First, HDOL, much in demand for polyester and polyurethanes, as well as by the pharmaceutical industry, is still produced from fossil raw materials [2]. The organic synthesis of DMA starts from benzene that is hydrogenated to cyclohexane, which is then oxidised in two stages to yield DMA [3]. The use of benzene, a carcinogenic coal- or petroleum-derived feedstock, can be avoided by replacing it with a sustainable biomass-derived feedstock, such as glucose. The catalytic oxidation of glucose to glucaric acid followed by its hydrodeoxygenation to adipic acid is a promising “green pathway” for HDOL production [4,5]. Moreover, even the subsequent esterification of adipic acid to DMA can use biomass-derived methanol. Second, the catalytic process of ester hydrogenolysis requires the use of copper- and chromium-based catalysts whose production requires the expensive disposal of the toxic chromium waste produced [2]. Moreover, the catalyst is only efficient under harsh energy-intensive conditions (T = 250 – 300 °C; pH2 = 250 – 300 bar) [6]. Thus, the development of a new environmentally friendly catalyst that is more active for ester hydrogenolysis and more selective to alcohols under energy-efficient reaction conditions is highly desirable. Furthermore, such an approach would contribute to the application of green chemistry principles. Many Cr-free Cu-based catalysts have been investigated for this purpose. Cu/ZnO catalysts are sufficiently active for DMA hydrogenolysis, resulting in a high feed conversion efficiency [2,7,8]. Despite this, the wider use of Cu/ZnO catalysts is limited by their drawbacks, which are primarily temperature related. At temperatures over 200 °C, the copper nanoparticles are liable to sintering [9], while at lower temperatures (160 – 205 °C), side reactions occur that reduce selectivity to the main product to just 30 – 50 % [8]. To prevent the copper nanoparticles in Cu/ZnO catalysts from sintering, Al2O3 could be added [10]. However, the presence of Al2O3 in Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalytic systems is known to have various disadvantages [2]. For example, Al2O3 possesses Lewis acid sites that can catalyse side reactions during ester hydrogenolysis, such as intramolecular esterification or alcohol dehydration, both of which unfavourably affect the selectivity to the targeted alcohol [11]. Furthermore, any Al-containing amorphous structure formed is difficult to characterize using conventional methods [2]. Despite these potential drawbacks, the addition of Al2O3 to Cu/ZnO has several benefits. It increases the thermal stability of the copper nanoparticles [7,10] and, consequently, enhances the dispersion of Cu species [12,13]. Moreover, this ternary system ensures the uniform dispersion of Cu in the Zn-Al matrix [14,15] and the stabilization of monovalent copper species on the catalyst surface [13,16]. The presence of Cu+ in such catalysts has been shown to enhance the adsorption of ester, which, in turn, can facilitate its subsequent hydrogenolysis [17,18]. In theory, the combination of these benefits should result in enhanced catalyst hydrogenolysis activity. Despite this, very few studies have investigated hydrogenolysis over Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts [2,7,19–21]. In this proof of concept study, we investigated the use of hydrotalcite-derived Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (hereafter abbreviated as CuZnAl) catalysts in DMA hydrogenolysis. To this purpose, five CuZnAl catalysts of different composition were synthesized and characterized as a basis for describing the changes that occurred in them as they move through their lifecycle from as-prepared precursors to spent samples. A combination of characterization techniques was used to provide a detailed investigation of the Cu active site, so important for hydrogenolysis, and its surroundings. Ultimately, we were able to elucidate the relationship between catalyst composition, structure, and activity in DMA hydrogenolysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis A series of five CuZnAl catalyst precursors and two reference samples (CuAl, ZnAl) were prepared by a co-precipitation method to obtain the targeted composition presented in Table 1. For the synthesis, a glass beaker was filled with distilled water and heated to 60 °C under stirring. The solution containing the corresponding metal nitrate precursors, i.e. Cu(NO3)2.3H2O (99.0 %, Penta, s.r.o., Czech Republic), Zn(NO3)2.6H2O (99.6 %, Lach:Ner, s.r.o., Czech Republic), and/or Al(NO3)3.9H2O (99.0 %, Lach:Ner, s.r.o., Czech Republic), and the basic solution of a precipitant were prepared and dosed simultaneously dropwise in the beaker by means of peristaltic pumps to keep a constant pH. After complete addition of both solutions, the resulting suspension was aged under stirring at 60 °C for 60 min. The prepared precipitate was filtered with the help of a vacuum pump, washed with distilled water and finally dried. The nomenclature of the obtained catalyst precursors and the applied synthesis conditions are detailed in Table S1. The nomenclature indicates the catalyst composition and pH used during the synthesis. For instance, CZ1.5A7(9) indicates a sample with Cu/Zn atomic ratio of 1.5 and (Cu+Zn)/Al atomic ratio of 7 synthesized at pH 9. These as-prepared precursors have the termination “_P”. The as-prepared precursors were calcined in a muffle oven in an air atmosphere with a heating rate of 2 °C·min−1 from room temperature (RT) to 350 or 650 °C and the final temperature was kept for 3 or 24 h. The calcination temperature used is reflected in the name of the calcined samples, e.g. CZ1.5A7(9)_350 stands for the catalyst precursor CZ1.5A7(9)_P calcined at 350 °C. To obtain reduced catalysts for characterization, the calcined precursors were reduced in 10 % H2/Ar (90 ml·min−1) where the temperature was gradually increased from RT to 220 °C (1 °C·min−1) and the final temperature was kept for 2 h. Then, the samples were cooled down to ambient temperature and flushed with nitrogen for 20 min. In the final stage, the reduced samples were passivated by 1 % O2/Ar that was flowing through the catalyst sample for 2 h at ambient conditions. The H2-reduced samples are denoted with the termination “_R”. The spent catalysts after their catalytic testing are denoted with the termination “_EXP”. 2.2 Characterization methods The Cu, Zn and Al contents were determined by atomic absorption spectrometry (AAS) using an Agilent 280FS AA spectrometer, where mixtures of acetylene and air or acetylene and N2O were used as an atomization flame. The phase composition of the samples and the size of crystallites of the relevant phases were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a diffractometer PANanalytical X′Pert3 Powder and CuKα radiation. The XRD patterns were recorded in a range of 2θ = 5 – 70°. Additionally, in situ XRD measurements were performed in a PANanalytical Empyrean X-ray diffractometer to study the thermal decomposition behaviour of selected catalyst precursors. To this purpose, the samples were exposed to an air flow of 60 ml·min−1 and the temperature raised from RT up to 350 °C at a heating rate of 3 °C·min−1. The crystallite sizes were estimated by line broadening analysis using the Scherrer’s equation. Reflections at 2θ = 31.8°, 43.3°, and 38.6° were used for calculating the crystallite size of ZnO, Cu0, and CuO phases, respectively [22]. The reducibility of copper oxide in the calcined precursors was determined by H2-TPR in a Quantachrome ChemStar TPx instrument with a TCD detector. The samples were exposed to a reducing gas mixture containing 10 vol % of hydrogen in argon with a flow of 50 ml·min−1. Typically, about 0.15 g of sample were introduced in a U-shaped reactor located in a furnace and treated with the reducing gas at a heating rate of 5 °C·min−1 from RT up to 600 °C. The hydrogen consumption was calculated using a calibration curve. Equilibrium adsorption isotherms of nitrogen were measured at − 196 °C for calcined and spent catalysts using a static volumetric adsorption system (TriFlex analyzer, Micromeritics, Norcross, USA). The samples were degassed at 200 °C for 12 h prior to N2 adsorption analysis, in order to obtain a clean surface. The adsorption isotherms were fitted using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method for the specific surface area (SBET) [23] and the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method for distribution of mesopores [24]. The copper particle size and size distribution of selected calcined precursors and passivated-reduced samples were determined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The measurements were carried out in a JEOL-JEM 2100F microscope operating at 200 kV. Prior to microscopy observation, the samples were suspended in isopropanol, ultrasonicated for 1 min, a drop extracted from the top of the suspension and deposited on a carbon-coated copper grid. About 300 particles from several images taken at different positions on the TEM grid were counted to obtain the corresponding particle size histograms. Copper surface areas (SCu) were measured by N2O chemisorption using the Reactive Frontal Chromatography (N2O-RFC) technique in an Autochem II 2920 (Micromeritics, USA) equipment connected online to a quadrupole mass spectrometer RGA 200 (Prevac) for monitoring of m/z = 28 (N2) and m/z = 44 (N2O) signals. The detailed procedure is described elsewhere [8]. Prior to measurements, the samples were reduced in situ under a flow of 10 vol % H2/Ar (30 ml·min−1) at 220 °C or 250 °C (heating rate of 5 °C·min−1) for 60 min. The SCu was calculated according to the procedure given in [25,26]. Cu dispersion (DCu) was estimated from N2O-RFC data using Eq. 1: (1) D Cu ( % ) = A N 2 · M Cu w Cu where A N 2 is the number of N2 moles released by the adsorption of N2O normalized to the standard conditions (0 °C; 101.325 kPa) (mol), w Cu is the copper mass in a measured sample (g), and M Cu is the atomic weight of Cu (g·mol−1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Setsys Evolution (Setaram, France) thermal analyzer. Samples were heated up to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 in He flow of 20 ml·min−1. IR spectra were recorded with a Thermo Nexus 8700 FTIR spectrometer using a DTGS detector and acquired at a resolution of 4 cm−1. A homemade IR cell allowing in situ treatments in controlled atmospheres and temperatures from −176 − 500 °C was connected to a vacuum system with a gas dosing facility. The samples were pressed into self-supported wafers of ∼10 mg. The NO adsorption experiments were done on calcined samples previously activated at 150 °C in vacuum (10−5 mbar) for 1 h. After activation, the samples were cooled down to −156 °C under dynamic vacuum conditions followed by NO dosing at increasing pressure (0.05 – 3 mbar). The CO adsorption experiments were carried out on reduced and spent samples. In the first case, pre-reduced and passivated samples were activated in N2 flow (20 ml·min−1) during temperature rising from 25 °C to 220 °C, at that temperature the flow was changed to H2 and kept for 2 h, followed by evacuation at 10−5 mbar at 270 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the samples were cooled down to −165 °C under dynamic vacuum (10−6 mbar) and CO dosed at increasing pressure (0.05 – 8 mbar). On the other hand, the spent samples were activated in N2 flow (20 ml·min−1) at 150 °C, then changed to H2 flow and kept at 150 °C for 1.5 h followed by evacuation at 150 °C for 1 h. After activation, the samples were cooled down to −165 °C under dynamic vacuum conditions (10−6 mbar) followed by CO dosing at increasing pressure (0.05 – 8 mbar). IR spectra were recorded after each dosage. Spectra were analysed using the Origin software. Raman spectra were recorded at ambient temperature with a 514 nm laser excitation on a Renishaw Raman Spectrometer (“in via”) equipped with a CCD detector. The laser power on the sample was 25 mW and a total of 20 acquisitions were taken for each spectrum. In some cases, analyses on different sample positions were recorded (spectral resolution ∼ 1 µm). NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD was measured using AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics) equipped with a TCD and an MS (Omnistar GSD320) detector. First, the calcined catalyst samples were heated to 350 °C in a helium atmosphere and after cooling down (to 70 °C for NH3 and 25 °C for CO2) 5 % NH3 in He (15 ml·min−1) or 10 % CO2 in He (25 ml·min−1) were introduced and NH3 or CO2, respectively, were adsorbed for 30 min. Then, physisorbed NH3 or CO2 were removed using helium flow (25 ml·min−1, 70 °C for NH3 and 25 °C for CO2, 1 h) and desorption of NH3 or CO2 was started by heating the catalyst sample at a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 at a constant He flow (25 ml·min−1). The amount of desorbed NH3 or CO2 was monitored by an MS detector. The reduced-passivated samples were re-reduced in situ in flow of 5 % H2/Ar at 220 °C for 20 min prior to the adsorption of NH3 or CO2, respectively. The results are presented as relative mass 16/4 (NH3) and 44/4 (CO2), where the m/z signals 16 and 44 were divided by the signal of He used as carrier gas to reach higher precision. X-ray photoelectron spectra were collected using a SPECS spectrometer with a Phoibos 150 MCD-9 detector and using a non-monochromatic AlKα (1486.6 eV) X-ray source. Spectra were recorded using an analyzer pass energy of 30 eV, an X-ray power of 100 W and under an operating pressure of 10−9 mbar. During data processing of the XPS spectra, binding energy (BE) values were referenced to the Al2p peak (74.5 eV). Spectra treatment was performed using the CASA software. For the measurements, ex-situ pre-reduced and passivated samples were re-reduced under flowing H2 (20 ml·min−1) at 220 °C for 2 h in a high-pressure catalytic cell (HPCR) connected under vacuum to the XPS analysis chamber. After reduction, the cell was evacuated and the samples were directly transferred to the XPS analysis chamber for measurement without being exposed to air. 2.3 Catalytic testing Four grams of calcined precursors (particle size 0.10 – 0.25 mm) were loaded into a fixed bed reactor between two layers of silicon carbide (particle size 0.25 – 0.30 mm) as an inert matrix. The reactor had 16 cm in length and its internal diameter was 0.85 cm. A thermocouple in a thermotube was located centrally along the longitudinal reactor axis. Prior to the reaction, the calcined precursors were reduced in-reactor by heating the reactor up to 220 °C in nitrogen atmosphere (SIAD, 99.9 %); then, hydrogen (SIAD, 99.999 %) was fed while its percentage in the mixture with nitrogen was gradually increased from 0 to 100 vol % for 2 h to prevent spontaneous catalyst overheating during the reduction. While the H2 concentration was 100 %, the reactor was pressurized from atmospheric pressure to 160 bar for 30 min. The heating was controlled and adjusted to avoid temperatures over 220 °C. For the experiments, dimethyl adipate (DMA, Merck, >99 %) was used as a feedstock. DMA flow rate of 16 g·h−1, WHSV of 4 gDMA·h−1·gcat −1, and H2/DMA molar ratio of 8 were set uniformly for all tested catalysts. Once a steady state was achieved, product samples were collected every 2 h at reaction temperatures of 160, 175, 190, and 205 °C and H2 pressure of 160 bar. We have previously experimentally confirmed that the tests were performed in absence of diffusional limitations [7]. Additional experiments at H2 pressures of 120 and 80 bar were performed over some catalysts as well. The collected samples were diluted in butanol (1:100 vol ratio) and analysed by GC-FID in a HP-5890 gas chromatograph with a 15 m non-polar ULTRA 1 column. During the experiment about 96 % of initial feedstock mass was recovered in the collected liquid products. Outgoing gaseous product contained evaporated methanol, a product of the hydrogenolysis, and negligible amounts of CO, CO2, and CH4 products along with unreacted H2. The conversion of dimethyl adipate (DMA) was evaluated using Eq. 2. Due to the absence of cracking reactions (confirmed by the GC analysis of the products), the C6 backbone of DMA as well as of the reaction products was used as a basis for the selectivity calculation (Eq. 3). Methanol was excluded, because it was present both in the liquid and gaseous product streams, which prevented its accurate quantification. Based on repeated experiments, the experimental error was determined to be less than 6 %. (2) conversion DMA % = n DMA , i − n DMA , t n DMA , i · 100 (3) S x % = n DMA , x n DMA , products · 100 where n DMA is the number of DMA moles, i is the initial amount of moles, t is the amount of moles at the sampling time, S x is the selectivity to product x, n DMA,x is the number of DMA moles converted to product x, n DMA,products is the number of DMA moles converted to all products. In order to compare the activity of the tested catalysts, the degree of hydrogenolysis (DH) that represents the percentage of ester groups that underwent hydrogenolysis, and the intrinsic activity or TOFH of metallic Cu species were calculated using Eq. 4 and Eq. 5, respectively. (4) DH = n 1 HMEol + 2 n HDOL + 3 n 2 Hdiol + 2 n 2 HMEol + n 2 HdiME + 4 n 3 Hdiol + 3 n 3 HMEol + 2 n 3 HdiME 2 n sample where n A is the number of moles of each particular product with an ester group hydrogenolyzed to a hydroxyl group, and n sample is the number of moles of products in the sample. (5) TOF H = v DMA . DH M DMA · σ Cu · N A m CAT · S Cu where v DMA is the DMA flow rate (g·h−1), DH is the degree of hydrogenolysis at 175 °C, M DMA is the molar mass of DMA (g·mol−1), N A is the Avogadro constant, m CAT is the mass of the catalyst (g), S Cu is the specific copper surface area (m2·gcat −1), and σCu is the Cu cross-sectional area equal to 0.0154 nm2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Five CuZnAl based precursors varying in molar Cu/Zn and Al/(Cu+Zn) ratios were prepared by co-precipitation to describe the influence of Cu/Zn and Al on catalyst properties and performance in DMA hydrogenolysis. In addition, CuAl and ZnAl precursors were synthesized as reference samples. The elemental composition of catalyst precursors and reference samples determined by AAS (Table 1) confirmed that the target values (Table S1) were successfully reached. The phase composition of the as-prepared precursors was determined by XRD. The simultaneous presence of Al3+ with Cu2+ and/or Zn2+ allowed the formation of a layered hydrotalcite-like phase (HTC) in the as-prepared catalyst precursors. The CA3(7)_P and ZA3(8)_P reference precursors contained predominantly CuAl- and ZnAl-HTC, respectively, with significant reflections at 2θ = 11.6° (003), 23.4° (006), 34.4° (012) and 60.2° (110) [27,28] accompanied by malachite Cu2(OH)2CO3 in CA3(7)_P and zinc hydroxide Zn(OH)2 in ZA3(8)_P ( Fig. 1a). The measured d-spacing of reflection (003) and calculated lattice parameters a and c of rhombohedral HTC structure in ZA3(8) and CA3(7) reference precursors helped to estimate the composition of the HTC phase in the CuZnAl samples (Table S2). By doing so, a Zn-rich HTC phase was concluded for the CuZnAl precursors, where about 28 – 57 % of Zn atoms (depending on sample composition) are replaced by Cu. In addition to the main HTC phase, CuO (2θ = 38.6°) and ZnO (2θ = 31.7°) phases were also present in the as-prepared CuZnAl precursors (Fig. 1a). Their presence was explained by the oxolation process occurring at relatively low temperatures and high pH, where CuO was formed via Cu(OH)2 [29]. The presence of HTC phase (bands at 495, 555, and 1055 cm−1) [30–32] and CuO (bands at 282, 330, and 615 cm−1) [33] was also confirmed by Raman spectroscopy as shown in Fig. 1b for the CZ1.5A3(9)_P precursor due to higher sensitivity of Raman spectroscopy compared to XRD. The thermal behaviour of catalyst precursors prior to calcination was studied by TGA-MS and in situ XRD. The TGA profiles of CuZnAl precursors, exemplified in Fig. S1a for CZ1.5A7(9)_P, showed that decomposition of the HTC structure occurred in three steps (detailed in the Supporting Information) which is in line with previous results [29,34,35], with total mass loss in the range of 20 – 31 wt % (Table S3). TGA-MS experiments confirmed that the samples mostly decomposed at temperatures below 350 °C with an associated mass loss of 17 – 25 wt %. The fact that samples with equivalent Al content (CZ1.0A5(9)_P, CZ1.5A5(9)_P, and CZ2.0A5(9)_P) exhibited the same 20 wt % mass loss up to 350 °C, and that those with an increasing Al content (CZ1.5A7(9)_P, CZ1.5A5(9)_P, CZ1.5A3(9)_P) showed an increasing mass loss of 17, 20, and 25 wt %, respectively, indicates that the mass loss is strongly connected to the Al content and thus to the presence of HTC-like phase. Further mass loss (ca. 5 wt %) occurring in the temperature range from 350 °C to 700 °C (Table S3) was related to the decomposition of “high-temperature carbonates”. Hand in hand with thermal decomposition, the phase composition was monitored by in situ XRD up to 350 °C. The crystalline HTC phase appeared completely decomposed at 150 °C in all samples, when the HTC phase reflections at 2θ = 11.6° and 23.4° disappeared, as illustrated in Fig. 2 for the sample CZ1.5A7(9)_P. The apparent discrepancy between TGA and XRD results can be explained by destruction of the crystalline HTC phase at < 150 °C followed by the transformation to oxides accompanied by H2O and CO2 release up to 350 °C as observed in TGA. Based on these results, the as-prepared precursors were calcined at 350 and 650 °C to observe changes in their structural properties corresponding to different degrees of the catalyst precursor decomposition. According to XRD patterns recorded for samples calcined at 350 and 650 °C, the crystallinity of all samples increased upon raising the calcination temperature (exemplified in Fig. S2 for CZ1.5A3(9)_P), where the peak of CuO (2θ = 38.6°) clearly became more intense and sharper and that of ZnO (2θ = 31.7°) turned XRD-visible at temperatures above 350 °C. As the temperature increased from 350° to 650°C, the BET surface area (SBET) decreased from 31 to 43 m2·g−1 to 22 – 33 m2·g−1 ( Table 2). This correlates with the increasing CuO particle sizes, estimated by XRD, from 4 to 5–6 – 12 nm (Table 2), indicative of a more pronounced particle sintering at the higher calcination temperature. The highest SBET (43 m2·g−1) after calcination at 350 °C was obtained for the sample CZ1.5A3(9) with the highest Al content. Indeed, as seen in Table 2, the SBET increased with the Al content at the constant Cu/Zn ratio but did not show an obvious correlation with the Cu/Zn ratio at constant Al content. Besides CuO and ZnO phases, a spinel-like phase, plausibly ZnAl2O4, was also detected after calcination at 650 °C (Fig. S2). Its amount increased as the Al content increased (Table S4). Generally, the formation of spinel-like phases could be explained by the decomposition of “high-temperature carbonates” occurring above 550 °C [36]. Moreover, the effect of calcination duration at 350 °C on the structural properties was also studied for the CZ1.5A7(9)_P precursor. According to XRD, H2-TPR, and N2 physisorption characterizations (not shown), an increase in calcination time from 3 to 22 h did not affect, within the experimental error, the phase composition, CuO crystallite size (5 – 6 nm in all cases), the extent of reduction (deviation in H2 consumption < 5 %), and SBET (deviation < 7 %) of the catalysts. Considering this, as well as the extensive CuO sintering observed upon calcination at 650 °C, all CuZnAl precursors in this work were calcined at 350 °C for 3 h for further characterization and catalytic studies. According to XRD, the crystalline HTC phase was decomposed to crystalline CuO and ZnO oxides after calcination at 350 °C for 3 h ( Fig. 3a). The absence of Al-containing phases can be attributed to the formation of Al2O3 typically exhibiting low crystallinity and/or of an amorphous (Cu,Zn)AlxOy(CO3)z phase [37–39]. Next to that, the ZnO phase was not detected in the XRD patterns of the two calcined precursors with Zn/Al atomic ratio below 1.6. The reason could be the interaction of ZnO and Al2O3 resulting in the formation of an XRD-invisible ZnAl-amorphous phase [15,20,40]. The most amorphous sample CZ1.5A3(9)_350 was investigated using Raman spectroscopy. Complementary to XRD, the presence of bulk CuO was also confirmed by the Raman bands at 282, 330, and 615 cm−1 [33,41] (Fig. 3b). Their wide shape suggests a high degree of material heterogeneity. Interestingly, the XRD-invisible ZnO was clearly identified by the presence of Raman features at 1050 and 1200 cm−1 [42]. The spinel-like phase in the calcined precursors was detected neither by XRD nor by Raman spectroscopy. Using TEM-EDS, the element spatial distribution of CZ1.5A3(9)_350 was examined (Fig. S3). Although both Al and Zn were detected and found to be uniformly dispersed over the catalyst surface, some Cu-rich regions were identified signing for a more heterogeneous distribution of copper (oxide) species, in conformity with Raman results. All these analyses suggest that Zn and Al formed a mixed amorphous matrix in which Cu nanoparticles are located. The CuO particle size in the calcined CuZnAl precursors was estimated by XRD to be in a narrow range of 4 – 5 nm (Table 2), close to the detection limit of the technique. Moreover, because of the poor crystallinity of the calcined CuZnAl catalysts, the estimation of particle sizes using Sherrer’s equation may be less accurate. To confirm particle size, the most amorphous sample CZ1.5A3(9)_350 was investigated in detail. In this sample, the average CuO particle size and the particle size distribution were analysed using TEM, where over 300 particles were measured. The TEM-derived particle size distribution is shown in Fig. 4a, where CuO particles in the size range of 1 – 6 nm were detected, with an average particle size of 3.1 nm. It is worth noting that about 50 % of CuO particles in this sample were found smaller than 3 nm and, thus, below the XRD detection limit. The presence of such small nanoparticles, undetectable by XRD, accounts for the higher average CuO particle size estimated by this technique in comparison with that directly measured by TEM. The surface composition of the calcined samples was investigated using XPS (more details in SI). Binding energies (BE) at the Cu2p3/2 and Zn2p3/2 core lines and respective Cu and Zn Auger parameters (α) are presented in Table S5, and the surface elemental composition is shown in Table 3. The BE of Cu2p3/2 and the satellite peak at 8.2 eV higher BE point to an oxidation state of + 2 for the surface Cu species in the calcined samples. Based on the Wagner plot evaluation (Fig. S4a) it corresponds likely to Cu(OH)2. When evaluating the BE of Zn2p3/2 (1021.9 ± 0.3 eV) together with the Auger parameter (α = 2009.5 ± 0.4 eV), it was concluded that Zn species in the outermost surface were present likely as Zn(OH)2 or as a ZnAl2O4-like phase rather than as ZnO (Fig. S4b). Nonetheless, XPS is a surface-sensitive technique and those hydroxides were not detected in catalyst bulk by XRD or Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 3). Also, huge discrepancies were found when comparing the bulk (Table 1) and surface (Table 3) composition of the samples. The surface enrichment by Zn (<1.5-times more) and Al (<2.1-times more) in most of the calcined catalysts was observed. As the Al content increased (at constant molar Cu/Zn) more surface Cu was visible. The reducibility of the calcined samples was assessed by means of H2-TPR (see SI, Fig. S5). The hydrogen consumption up to 300 °C was over 95 % of the total hydrogen consumed in the H2-TPR experiments for all tested samples. The calcined catalysts were reduced by an H2/inert mixture (10 vol % H2) at 220 °C for 2 h to obtain the catalytically active Cu species. The copper specific surface area (SCu) determined using N2O-RFC ranged from 3 to 6 m2·gcat −1. Nonetheless, the in-reactor reduction prior to the catalytic experiment was performed at 220 °C and atmospheric pressure followed by pressurizing the reactor to 160 bar, while prior to N2O chemisorption the reduction was done only at atmospheric pressure. Consequently, a nearly full reduction of CuO nanoparticles was achieved during the in-reactor reduction, whereas only 35 – 74 % reduction was observed prior to N2O-RFC at 220 °C. This could mean that the conditions used prior to N2O-RFC were not sufficient to simulate the in-reactor reduction. Thus, the reduction temperature was increased to 250 °C prior to N2O-RFC to enhance the extent of copper reduction and thus to compensate for the difference in hydrogen pressure. At this reduction temperature, the copper reducibility significantly raised to 91 – 97 %, practically matching that expected for the in-reactor reduction, resulting in SCu values ranging from ca. 6–8 m2·gcat −1 ( Table 4). Interestingly, the catalysts with a constant Al content exhibited a constant relative increase in SCu and in the reducibility of about 50 % with respect to the samples pre-reduced at 220 °C, while the SCu and reducibility of catalysts with a constant Cu/Zn ratio increased by about 23 %, 50 %, and 103 % as the Al content increased. It can thus be concluded that the higher Al content decreased the reducibility of CuZnAl catalysts. To compare the activity of CuZnAl catalysts expressed as TOF, the values of SCu obtained after reduction at 250 °C, where a nearly full copper reduction was attained, were used. Next to the SCu, both the size and stability of metallic Cu nanoparticles are essential from the catalyst performance point of view. As shown in Table 4, the XRD-derived Cu0 crystallite sizes ranged from 5 to 11 nm, while CuO crystallites sizing 4 – 5 nm were obtained in the calcined samples as determined by XRD (Table 2). The results indicate little sintering during the reduction process. The growth in Cu particle size after reduction is more pronounced at lower Al contents demonstrating, thus, a positive effect of Al on the stability of Cu nanoparticles. The Cu0 particle size distribution was evaluated by TEM in the CZ1.5A3(9)_R sample, where an average Cu0 nanoparticle size of 3.9 nm was obtained (Fig. 4b). Comparing the TEM-based nanoparticle size distribution of the calcined and reduced CZ1.5A3(9) samples (Fig. 4), a slight shift towards larger sizes is observed after reduction due to sintering. Nonetheless, as XRD could not detect the presence of the smallest nanoparticles, the TEM values are reasonably lower. Using a theoretical model of spherical Cu particles, such small Cu0 nanoparticles of about 4 nm (according to TEM) should exhibit approximately 10-times larger SCu in CZ1.5A3(9)_R than that ascertained by N2O-RFC. We suggest that this large discrepancy between characterization techniques could be explained by a grapes-shaped model. The small Cu nanoparticles visible by XRD/TEM are packed together bonded with the ZnAl matrix forming a 3D model of grapes where only about 10 % of Cu is on the surface and, thus, available to N2O used in the RFC method. However, the rest of Cu is not available for N2O, but available for H2 as confirmed by the > 90 % reducibility. Alternatively, the reduced Cu can be covered partially by a layer of the ZnAl matrix that would stabilize the small Cu nanoparticles (as seen by TEM and XRD) while limiting access to the reduced Cu sites (as seen by the lower N2O adsorption than expected for the Cu nanoparticle size determined by TEM). To provide an important insight into the surface composition that is relevant to catalytic performance rather than the bulk one, and into the catalyst changes during reduction, the XPS spectra of reduced catalysts were acquired (more details in Supporting Information). The binding energy (BE) along with the Auger parameter (α) for Cu and Zn species are gathered in Table S6, and the surface elemental composition is given in Table 3. The Cu2p3/2 BE and the CuL3M4,5M4,5 Auger kinetic energy (KE) were present in all samples at 932.3 ± 0.3 eV and 918.6 ± 0.2 eV (Fig. S6), respectively, resulting in an Auger parameter (α) of 1850.9 ± 0.3 eV characteristic of Cu0 [43]. This indicates that Cu was present as Cu0 in all reduced samples. The absence of a component at KE ∼ 916.6 eV rules out the presence of Cu+, at least within the XPS detection limit [43]. The BE of Zn2p3/2 (1021.9 ± 0.3 eV) and the Auger parameter (α = 2009.5 ± 0.4 eV) values shown in Table S6 along with the Wagner plot of reference Zn compounds (Fig. S4b) suggest that Zn species on the catalyst surface were present as Zn(OH)2 or as a ZnAl2O4-like phase rather than as ZnO detected by XRD in the bulk. The evaluated surface composition of the reduced samples significantly differed from that of the calcined samples (Table 3). In particular, the atomic Al surface concentration in the reduced samples (35 – 56 %) was 1.4 – 2.3 times higher than in the calcined precursors. Conversely, the atomic surface concentration of Cu largely decreased from 24 % to 39 % in the calcined samples to only 13 – 22 % after reduction. These changes in the surface composition point towards an important reconstruction of the catalyst surface during the reduction process. On the other hand, the atomic concentration of Zn on the surface experienced a slight decrease of ca. 10 – 30 % after reduction with respect to the calcined precursors. Using TEM-EDS, the element spatial distribution of CZ1.5A3(9)_R was examined revealing the uniform dispersion of each element over the catalyst surface (Fig. S3). Previously, it was suggested that the surface can be covered by CuZn alloy [44–46]. Its possible formation could be examined by XRD [47,48]. The lattice parameter a of Cu (111) facet is about 0.3615 nm for pure Cu (111) and, as Zn dissolves in Cu, the lattice parameter linearly grows as reported by Bayer (e.g. 10 % dissolved Zn in Cu corresponds to 0.363 nm) [47]. Yao et al. reported the lattice parameter of 0.362 nm in case of Cu/C [17]. In this study, the lattice parameter a was calculated to be in the range of 0.3617 – 0.3622 nm for the reduced catalysts (Table 4). These values do not differ remarkably from those for pure Cu (111). The sample CZ1.5A7(9)_R with the highest a can contain up to 3 % of dissolved Zn in Cu. Hence, considering the lattice parameter a and Cu and Zn oxidation states discussed above, the formation of a CuZn alloy was not confirmed within analysis detection limit. The spent catalysts were investigated using N2 physisorption, XRD, FTIR-CO, and N2O-RFC to probe catalyst active sites and reveal changes in the catalyst structure during the catalytic reaction. The SBET significantly increased after reaction, reaching the highest value of 95 m2·g−1 in case of the CZ1.5A3(9)_EXP catalyst. The SBET of all spent catalysts was about 2.2 – 2.3-times higher than the SBET of the calcined samples, indicating the same proportional structural reorganization in all the catalysts. As shown beforehand, the structural reorganization occurred not only during the reaction, but to some extent also during catalyst reduction as indicated by XPS data. Based on the XRD data, the Cu0 crystallite sizes ranged from 8 to 17 nm. In general, catalysts showing smaller Cu0 crystallites corresponded to those displaying higher SBET after reaction (Table 4). Moreover, according to XRD, the average Cu0 particle size of all catalysts increased after catalysis with respect to the values of the corresponding reduced samples (Table 4), which is the evidence for agglomeration of the Cu nanoparticles during the catalytic reaction itself. Taking into account the catalysts with constant Cu/Zn ratio, the Cu0 particle size decreased and the SBET increased as the Al content increased, which further confirms the positive influence of Al incorporation on stabilizing the Cu nanoparticles. In order to properly investigate the active Cu site and its oxidation state, FTIR of CO as a probe molecule has been done. As a representative, in Fig. S7 the IR-CO spectra of reduced and spent samples are shown for CZ1.0A5(9) and CZ1.5A3(9). Both samples exhibit IR bands assigned to Cu+-CO carbonyls of highly dispersed Cu+ species in different local environments (2141 – 2130 cm−1) [49], slightly oxidised surface copper species, i.e. Cu2O surface patches or Cuδ+ at the Cu-ZnO interface (2120–2114 cm−1), and linear Cu0-CO carbonyls on high-indexed Cu0 (110) and (100) planes (2100 – 2099 cm−1 and 2088 – 2083 cm−1, respectively) [50]. As observed, besides the decrease in the total intensity of the copper-related IR bands, specifically in the CZ1.0A5(9) sample, in both samples the fraction of Cu+ versus Cu0 decrease after reaction (Table S7). The fact that Cu+ species are detected by IR-CO while not by XPS, is due to the higher surface sensitivity of IR spectroscopy using CO as probe molecule. In Fig. 5 are presented the IR spectra of three selected spent catalysts (CZ1.0A5(9), CZ1.5A3(9), and CZ1.5A7(9)) as the catalysts in spent state are the most relevant to the catalysis data. Their respective peak areas normalized to sample weight are compiled in Table 5 and those differences in the proportion between Cu+ and Cu0 could signify different catalytic behaviour. Further details will be discussed below in the section related to catalyst activity. To quantify Cu0 species, the spent samples were subjected to N2O chemisorption. As we pointed out above, the catalysts experienced structural changes during the catalyst reduction and catalytic experiment. In addition, some Cu species might have been blocked due to coke formation that could account for the decreased intensity of the IR-CO signals in the spent samples with respect to the reduced counterparts. Thus, a decrease in SCu could be expected for the spent samples in comparison with their as-reduced counterparts. As it can be observed in Table 4, SCu decreased in the order CZ1.0A5(9)_EXP (5.2 m2·gcat −1) > CZ1.5A3(9)_EXP (4.1 m2·gcat −1) > CZ1.5A7(9)_EXP (2.4 m2·gcat −1). This nicely fits with catalyst hydrogenolysis activity as demonstrated below. Compared to the reduced samples, a drop in SCu of about 26 %, 30 %, and 70 %, respectively, was observed. The catalyst with the lowest Cu content, CZ1.0A5(9), had the highest SCu. At constant Cu/Zn ratio, the higher SCu of CZ1.5A3(9) compared to CZ1.5A7(9) indicated that a higher Al content facilitated the stabilization of Cu0 species. 3.2 DMA hydrogenolysis on CuZnAl catalysts The calcined CuZnAl catalyst precursors were reduced in-reactor at 220 °C and tested in dimethyl adipate (DMA) hydrogenolysis. Previously, we reported that ZnO did not possess any hydrogenolysis activity and the activity of CuO as a single-phase catalyst as well as of a commercial CuCr catalyst was significantly lower than that of a CuZnAl catalyst [7,8]. The change in the DMA conversion with the reaction temperature for the CuZnAl catalysts is presented in Fig. 6a. In course of the tests, a broad range of conversions from 8 % to 99 % was covered. The maximum DMA conversion at 205 °C of 99 % was reached over CZ1.0A5(9) having the lowest Cu content and Cu/Zn ratio of 1. This same ratio was shown to be the most efficient for ester hydrogenolysis over CuZn catalysts [8]. Among the catalysts with the constant Cu/Zn ratio, the best performance in terms of DMA conversion was observed over CZ1.5A3(9) having the highest Al content, although it was still lower than the performance of CZ1.0A5(9). To determine the specific catalytic activity per an accessible copper atom, turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated. Besides the desired hydrogenolysis reaction, also transesterification occurs under these reaction conditions (described in detail below) [7,51]. Thus, the conversion of ester functional groups to alcohol called the degree of hydrogenolysis (DH) was evaluated. This helped to precisely calculate the catalyst activity related only to hydrogenolysis as TOFH (Fig. 6b). In line with the trends observed for the DMA conversion, an increase in TOFH with the increasing Al content at constant Cu/Zn ratio and with the decreasing Cu/Zn ratio at a constant Al content was also observed. The TOFH value was in the range of 1.5·10−3 – 5.5·10−3 s−1. Previously, we have reported that the hydrogenolysis activity of a CuZnAl catalyst (TOFH = 0.9·10−3 s−1) is comparable to CuZn catalysts, but higher than that of CuMg or CuCr catalysts [7]. In this current study, the intrinsic hydrogenolysis activity (TOFH) of Cu0 in the CuZnAl catalysts was significantly improved due to the improved catalyst properties. This is attributed to the change in catalyst precursor synthesis, in particular to the use of higher pH 9 resulting in the induced formation of hydrotalcite in as-prepared precursors. The TOFH of CZ1.5A7(9) and CZ1.5A5(9) catalysts (ca. 1.5·10−3 s−1) was comparable with the value reached over the previously reported CuZnAl catalyst, but remarkably higher TOFH values (ca. 4·10−3 – 5.5·10−3 s−1) were reached for the rest of catalysts in the present work (Fig. 6b). According to the results shown in Fig. 6, the catalyst CZ1.0A5(9) displayed the highest DMA conversion and TOFH. Several parameters could help to explain it: i) the catalyst had the highest surface Zn content and we previously determined Zn as the best promoter [7] that acts as Lewis acid site enhancing ester adsorption [17,18,52]; ii) the optimal Cu/Zn ratio equal to 1 was used [8]; iii) the highest Cu dispersion was achieved, and iv) high and stable SCu during the hydrogenolysis. Nonetheless, it was previously shown that the presence of Cu+ species also enhanced the hydrogenolysis activity of Cu-based catalysts [17,18,52]. Thus, we studied here three spent catalysts with different catalytic performances (CZ1.0A5(9), CZ1.5A3(9), and CZ1.5A7(9)) in detail using FTIR-CO and N2O-RFC (Table 4 and Table 5). Interestingly, both Cu+/Cutotal and Cu+/Cu0 ratios increased in the opposite order to the order of increasing catalytic activity, i.e. CZ1.0A5(9)_EXP < CZ1.5A3(9)_EXP < CZ1.5A7(9)_EXP (Table 5 and Fig. 6). This indicates that Cu+ species would not play a relevant role in the DMA hydrogenolysis reaction on CuZnAl catalysts, in contrast to previous studies where Cu+ was suggested to enhance the hydrogenolysis activity by providing additional sites for ester adsorption [17,53–55]. Besides, the SCu (Table 4) nicely fits with the catalyst hydrogenolysis activity as both decreased in the order CZ1.0A5(9)_EXP (5.2 m2·gcat −1) > CZ1.5A3(9)_EXP (4.1 m2·gcat −1) > CZ1.5A7(9)_EXP (2.4 m2·gcat −1). The best hydrogenolysis performance was reached for catalyst CZ1.0A5(9) having the lowest Cu+/Cu0 and highest SCu determined in the spent sample. The performance of CuZnAl catalysts depended on SCu rather than on the presence of Cu+, which suggested that SCu was the most important catalyst parameter to achieve high hydrogenolysis activity. The complete hydrogenolysis of DMA yields hexane-1,6-diol (HDOL) as the main product. A reaction intermediate, methyl 6-hydroxyhexanoate (1HMEol), is produced by hydrogenolysis of only one of two methyl ester groups in DMA. Hydrogenolysis reactions are accompanied by transesterification reactions [7,56]. These compounds are formed by transesterification between DMA, HDOL and/or 1HMEol (whole reaction pathway is depicted in Fig. 7) [51,57]. The tested reaction conditions covered full range of DMA conversion and, thus, a comparison at iso-conversion conditions can be provided. The selectivity to the main products is presented in Fig. 8 and Fig. S9 as a function of the DMA conversion. At low conversions (<10 %), many products were observed. First, the reaction intermediate 1HMEol was observed with a selectivity from 50 % to 70 %. Also, some of 1HMEol was converted to the main product HDOL reaching a selectivity up to 25 %. Besides, a part of 1HMEol was converted to transesterification by-products (TR) with a selectivity up to 30 %. As the DMA conversion increased up to 80 – 85 %, the selectivity to the intermediate (1HMEol) linearly decreased, while the HDOL selectivity increased only slightly from 20 % to 40 %. A more pronounced increase in selectivity from 20 % to 50 % was observed for the transesterification products. When the DMA conversion exceeded 85 %, the HDOL selectivity steeply grew which was attributed to the conversion of TR by-products to HDOL. All catalysts followed the same qualitative selectivity trends and the maximum HDOL selectivity of 86 % was reached over CZ1.0A5(9) due to the highest reached DMA conversion (>99 %). To compare our results, Yuan et al. tested similar co-precipitated CuZnAl catalyst that reached, depending on calcination temperature (400 – 600 °C), DMA conversion between 85 % and 99 % and HDOL selectivity between 91 % and 99 %. Nevertheless, the comparison with our results is not straightforward due to the higher temperature (205 vs. 215 °C), lower pressure (80 vs. 50 bar), significantly lower LHSV (4 vs. 0.5 h−1), and substantially higher H2/ester ratio (8 vs 30) were used in the work by Yuan et al. [2]. The differences in selectivity can also be attributed to differences in the acid-base properties of the catalysts. Previously, we have observed that the higher number of acid-base sites resulted in a lower selectivity to 1HMEol or HDOL while the formation of TR products was augmented [7,58,59]. Thus, the acid-base properties of calcined CuZnAl catalysts were investigated by NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD and the results are compiled in Table S8. Except of CZ1.0A5(9) having the highest hydrogenolysis activity less inducing TR formation, the rest of the catalysts having a higher number of acid-base sites supported the TR formation. An in-depth analysis of the transesterification by-products revealed that among 2 H compounds (formed by two hexane fragments), 2HMEol was the most abundant one. Moreover, the CZ1.5A7(9) and CZ1.5A5(9) catalysts reached higher TR selectivity due to the low hydrogenolysis activity (TOFH) compared to the rest of the catalysts. In other words, 1HMEol was more likely to react with DMA to form 2HdiME (Fig. S9b) than to be hydrogenolyzed to HDOL. The CZ2.0A5(9) catalyst was tested for 48 h at T = 175 °C to study its stability (Fig. S10). The DMA conversion and HDOL selectivity were stable (at about 64 % and 31 %, respectively) during the experiment. Thus, we have concluded the catalyst was stable in DMA hydrogenolysis under the selected operating conditions. According to our previous study [60], these results are transferable to other esters as the ester conversion decreased only slightly with the carbon chain length of the ester, while the selectivity remained constant. Moreover, the influence of hydrogen pressure on the catalyst performance was also assessed by performing catalytic experiments at 160, 120, and 80 bar at the temperature of 205 °C ( Fig. 9, Fig. S11, Fig. S12). Comparing the results in Fig. 9a, the DMA conversion decreased as the pressure decreased, which highlighted the importance of H2 pressure for the DMA hydrogenolysis. This was accompanied by a decrease in the HDOL selectivity, because of the strong relationship between those parameters as presented in Fig. 8a. In more detail, the decrease in HDOL selectivity was due to the lower rate of hydrogenolysis of TR products in comparison with the hydrogenolysis of DMA, in the studied hydrogen pressure range. But, it is not rigorous to compare the decrease in absolute numbers. A better comparison is seen in Fig. 9b, where no significant effect of the higher reaction pressure on the HDOL selectivity is observed. This could preliminary suggest Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism with an ester adsorption being the rate-limiting step. However, further specific experimental studies are still needed to uncover the mechanistic aspects of DMA hydrogenolysis. We suggest that the ester adsorption is supported by the presence of Lewis acid sites, i.e. it takes place at the Cu-ZnAl or Cu0-Cu+ interfaces. This would also imply that in order to further improve the catalyst performance, one needs to increase the number of interface sites to enhance the ester adsorption. 4 Conclusions As the green chemistry principles are being implemented, the use of Adkins catalysts for ester hydrogenolysis is being gradually restricted. Therefore, environmentally-friendly Cr-free catalysts are being searched. In this study, the structural properties of co-precipitated CuZnAl catalysts were systematically studied in each preparation step from the as-prepared precursors to the reduced and spent catalysts. Using XRD, the structure of the mixed CuZnAl-hydrotalcite phase was identified in the as-prepared precursors. The Cu incorporation into the ZnAl-hydrotalcite phase was revealed. The CuO and Cu particle sizes were examined by TEM and XRD. The results were in agreement and the size increased from 4 to 5 nm to 5 – 11 nm during the reduction and to 8 – 17 nm during the hydrogenolysis experiments. The surface composition determined by XPS showed that the surface was enriched by Zn and Al compared to the bulk composition. Based on the change in the surface composition during the catalytic tests, we suggest that catalyst reconstruction resulting in higher Al content on the catalyst surface took place. This reconstruction was further corroborated by the increase in BET surface area. To understand the catalyst hydrogenolysis behaviour, the Cu active sites and its environment were studied in detail. The SCu in reduced catalysts reached 6 – 8 m2·g−1 and the presence of both Cu+ and Cu0 species was detected by FTIR-CO. It was found that although the increasing Al content decreased the catalyst reducibility, it also made the catalyst more resistant to sintering and resulted in smaller Cu nanoparticles. Finally, the catalysts were used in dimethyl adipate hydrogenolysis (T = 160 – 205 °C, p H2 = 80 – 160 bar) to evaluate their activity and selectivity. A large range of DMA conversions from 8 % to 99 % was achieved. The TOFH was calculated to describe intrinsic copper hydrogenolysis activity. Among the samples, higher activity was achieved by reducing Cu content and increasing the Al/(Cu+Zn) ratio. Interestingly, the most active catalyst, CZ1.0A5(9), had the lowest Cu content among the studied catalysts. Nonetheless, it had the highest Cu dispersion, SCu and optimum ratio of Cu/Zn = 1 that contributed to the highest activity of the Cu nanoparticles in this catalyst. These parameters were more relevant than the presence of Cu+. Importantly, all studied catalysts outperformed previously tested CuCr catalyst in terms of DMA conversion. Moreover, the used reaction conditions are more efficient than those originally used for CuCr catalyst. For the tested catalysts, the HDOL selectivity was mostly dependent on the DMA conversion rather than on the catalyst composition. For further development to achieve an increase in TOFH, the catalyst composition could be further optimized by using promoters or deposition of the Cu nanoparticles on a suitable support could be considered. coredata.dc:description: Ester hydrogenolysis is industrially performed over Adkins catalysts. Their use is being restricted as they contain environmentally unfriendly Cr2O3. As a potential replacement, five co-precipitated CuZnAl catalysts with various Cu/Zn and Al/(Cu+Zn) atomic ratios were studied. The structure transformation during the whole catalyst lifecycle was determined. The catalyst precursors consisted of CuZnAl-hydrotalcite (HTC). Although the Cu/Zn ratio did not affect the HTC structure, an increase in Al content resulted in smaller Cu nanoparticles with a larger surface area. In the reduced catalysts, both Cu+ and Cu0 species were identified using FTIR-CO. XPS revealed catalyst surface reconstruction after catalyst reduction and catalytic reaction. The evaluation of the catalysts in dimethyl adipate hydrogenolysis indicated that the catalyst having the lowest Cu loading possessed the highest activity, due to its high SCu and Cu/Zn = 1. Generally, higher activity was achieved by reducing the Cu/Zn and increasing the Al/(Cu+Zn) ratios.
coredata.dc:title: CuZnAl hydrotalcites as suitable precursors for chromium-free ester hydrogenolysis catalysts
